Things I’m loving right now:
1. Having my Christmas tree as a default backdrop
2. Hot coffee because it’s cold in FL today
3. WHITE HORSE by @erikatwurth 😍

I’m #currentlyreading this book and what I love so far is that while it’s creeping me out to the fullest degree, the topic of grief is handled extremely well. 

In this chiller, we are Kari as she lives her life drinking beer at the White Horse while reading Stephen King novels with her cousin, Debby. Debby finds this old bracelet that belonged to Kari’s Indian mother. This bracelet calls up her mother’s ghost and a monstrous entity. Kari has been ignoring her past for far too long and now has no other decision but to face it head on. 

I do know that while this is creepy at first, it does get a little more serious as the pages turn. I’m intrigued by that. It’s not something I’m used to reading and I’m looking forward to finishing this as my first December read!

Thank you @booksparks for allowing me to be a part of the #booksparksbookclub 😍

If you’re looking for that *last* book to add to your December TBR that will just end the year on a five star, these are my recommendations! Each of these books made me feel, gasp, or surprised the heck out of me. I hope you save this and add these to your reading list if you haven’t yet. Swipe over to see covers! 

THE GRACE YEAR by Kim Liggett - one of the only YA books I’ve ever been surprised by

THE APPEAL by Janice Hallett - entire story told through emails, voicemails, newspaper clippings, etc. very quick read and a great mystery

MY LOVELY WIFE by Samantha Downing - a husband and wife get their kicks by killing people together. Amazing twist. 

THE FASECLUDED CABIN SLEEPS SIX by Lisa Unger - this thriller made me feel things that most thrillers don’t. The POVs were super interesting and came together in a way you don’t expect 

LITTLE EVE by Catriona Ward - a cult book that was done extremely well. Deserves more hype

THE ONE by John Marrs - still one of the best thrillers I’ve ever read. Wish I could reread for the first time. DNA tests determine your perfect match with MULTIPLE POVs that aren’t confusing 

MALIBU RISING by Taylor Jenkins Reid - not my fave TJR (Daisy Jones will hold that spot forever) but the family dynamic in this book will always be a favorite of mine

THE FAMILY GAME by Catherine Steadman - ugh this was just so fun (AND SET AT CHRISTMAS TIME TOO) low key freaked me out at times and I loved it

IM GLAD MY MOM DIED by Jennette McCurdy - I just loved this memoir as I grew up watching her on iCarly. Heartbreaking story but tells about how strong she is 

Have you read any of these? 
Any you’re adding to your TBR?

Rating: 3.5 ⭐️⭐️⭐️✨
Genre: thriller
Page count: 320 pages
Read if you:
-enjoy stories about twins
-enjoy two POVs
-need short chapters
-wish you could pack up and move somewhere where no one knows you and start over

We are following Connie Foster as she is learning she inherited a house in a small, New Mexico town after her wealthy mother died. Her twin sister gets everything, but all Connie gets is this derelict house and a bunch of stipulations. Typical, as her mother always hated her and played psychological games with her growing up. Whatever. 

This town has a haunted past of serial killers, women disappearing, and townies who refuse to talk about what’s going on. Now that Connie has moved into town, the killings have started again. And the people she speaks with are targets. Maybe to send her a message to stop asking questions. 

The second timeline is set in 1997 when their mother first comes to town in search of her missing daughter, Kelsey. In all actuality, Eve is a BA woman who knows what she wants and how to get it. And she wants her daughter back. 

Thoughts:
So I really loved both storylines. I loved how they both took place in the same little town and how Eve’s story was leaving little breadcrumbs for Connie’s story. They flowed seamlessly. 

What got me a little was the timing of the POVs. I know why Eve’s story was the length it was, but I could tell Connie’s story could have been wrapped up a little quicker had we not had to wait for the other timeline. It’s something easily looked over, though. 

The reveals have me feeling different ways. Some I definitely saw coming, although that’s not a ding to the book! I just read a lot of thrillers. Others took me by surprise which was so fun! Some made complete sense. The others I had to suspend disbelief a little. Again, I don’t care about that, I just would personally prefer either all or none of the reveals make me suspend. 

I thoroughly enjoyed this and would still 100% recommend! 

Thank you @crookedlanebooks for my #gifted copy of this book in exchange for an honest review! Out now!

Couldn’t even put the book down on my wedding day 😂 I was just reminiscing and found this gem!

I thought I was smarter than this book. I am now humbling myself to declare that I was in fact not more intelligent than this plot.

Rating: 5 stars
Genre: Mystery/Thriller
Page Count: 416 pages (I listened via audio!)
A Goodreads Best Mystery Thriller Nominee! (and for good reason)

READ THIS IF...
-you enjoy time travel stories
-time travel doesn't confuse you
-you enjoy a little science fiction in your every day stories
-you often wish you could "go back to the good ole days"
-like family oriented shows

SYNOPSIS:
Can you stop a murder after it's already happened? 
Late October. After midnight. You’re waiting up for your seventeen-year-old son. He’s late. As you watch from the window, he emerges, and you realize he isn’t alone: he’s walking toward a man, and he’s armed.

Every morning you wake up a day earlier, another day before the murder. With another chance to stop it. Somewhere in the past lies an answer. The trigger for this crime—and you don’t have a choice but to find it...

MY THOUGHTS:
I was talking with @books_wine_and_sunshine while I was reading this book. I told her I thought it was too long and could be told without such a verbose page count. She told me to keep going because at the end, it all made sense. By the time I read the ending, every single page mattered. This story could not be told without every page. It feels a little slow going through, but the payout is worth it. 

This story taught me a few things, which thrillers don't do. It taught me to enjoy the small moments in life as they don't come back, to entertain people's interests and allow them to talk about them/ask questions even if I'm not personally interested in said topic, and to not take everything so seriously. If you read this, you'll pick up why these lessons are there. But it made an impact on me that most mysteries don't.

This is more mystery than thriller. I knew that going in so my expectations were tampered. If the high page count is intimidating, the audio book is fantastic. It might feel a little repetitive when reading her day to day, and you might feel as if you have it figured out from the middle of it. You don't, trust me. Just read this one. 

10/10 recommend.

If this was inspired by the Manson murders, then the Manson murders were not horrendous at all. This is marketed as a mystery thriller, but it's more historical fiction with a timeline set in the present day.

Read this if you...
-really enjoy historical fiction mixed with present day
-enjoy dual timelines and POVs
-like longer chapters
-like reading about social media influencers
-enjoy stories following musicians

Synopsis:
As kids, Emily and Chess were inseparable. But by their 30s, their bond has been strained by the demands of their adult lives. So when Chess suggests a girls trip to Italy, Emily jumps at the chance to reconnect with her best friend. As Emily digs into the villa’s complicated history, she begins to think there might be more to the story of a fateful summer in 1974 that ended in murder. That perhaps Pierce’s murder wasn’t just a tale of sex, drugs, and rock & roll gone wrong, but that something more sinister might have occurred––and that there might be clues hidden in the now-iconic works that Mari and Lara left behind.

My Thoughts:
I buddy read this with @bookwithcollins and struggled. As a 288 page book, it felt like it was a 588 page book. The chapters were extremely long with seemingly no payout. Each storyline took it's time with their side of the story but felt as if it said nothing. I made it 130 pages in before the repetitiveness changed to the next topic. I could have skimmed and still gotten the story line, plot, and conclusion due to the repeating nature of the story.

The present story is just a main character complaining about her "best friend" while simultaneously using her for a free vacation, all while having writer's block. The past timeline is a main character desiring her cheating partner to change when everyone knows he won't. 

I will say the story within the story is what saved a star for me. I genuinely enjoyed present timeline reading the past timeline's book and learning about the past while staying in the same house. 

There was untapped potential to this book and it left me more disappointed than anything, unfortunately.

THE VILLA
⭐️⭐️
By Rachel Hawkins

Contrary to popular (and very correct) belief that I only read the macabre, I have a few general fiction/memoirs that made it to my 2022 faves list! See? I can read not-thriller things… sometimes…

The Boys’ Club by Erica Katz
Mary Jane by Jessica Anya Blau
Lucky by Marissa Stapely 
Carrie Soto is Back by Taylor Jenkins Reid
I’m Glad my Mom Died by Jennette McCurdy
Malibu Rising by Taylor Jenkins Reid
Friends, Lovers, and the Big Terrible Thing by Matthew Perry

Slide to see covers!

Any we agree or disagree on?

I couldn’t end 2022 without hearing from Matthew Perry. Could I BE any more correct about loving THE Chandler Bing?

Matthew mainly focuses on his struggle with the disease of addiction and alcoholism. While he touches on his time on FRIENDS and other projects, he tells the nitty gritty on what addiction is, feels like, how horrible it is, and how he is still dealing with it. 

This was hard to read. 

I’ve seen negative reviews regarding how he comes across as arrogant or how the writing is off. I disagree. While there are some repetitive parts to the book, I didn’t see arrogance come off the page. I saw a glimpse into who Matthew Perry is, his true personality. It didn’t sound heavily edited. While that’s a negative for some, I appreciated how raw (and almost flawed) it read. I felt as if I was really in his mind as he was writing and who he genuinely is, not a part of him who was edited out. 

This is not a tell-all for FRIENDS, this is a tell-all for Matthew Perry. 

I loved it. 

Plus there are pictures!

FRIENDS, LOVERS, AND THE BIG TERRIBLE THING
Matthew Perry

This book immediately breaks the fourth wall and gives 10 mystery rules it would follow. Because of this, I knew it was smarter than me and just went along for the ride.

You should too.

EVERYONE IN MY FAMILY HAS KILLED SOMEONE
By: Benjamin Stevenson
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Read this if you like..
-everyone has a secret
-all plot points come together in multiple ways at the end
-multiple twists
-when the author speaks to the reader
-feel as if you can predict every thriller
-The 7 1/2 Deaths of Evelyn Hardcastle

Synopsis:
Everyone in my family has killed someone. Some of us, the high achievers, have killed more than once. I'm not trying to be dramatic, but it is the truth. Some of us are good, others are bad, and some just unfortunate.

I'm Ernest Cunningham. I wish I'd killed whoever decided our family reunion should be at a ski resort, but it's a little more complicated than that.

Have I killed someone? Yes. I have.

Who was it?

Let's get started.

Thoughts:
Man this was fun. I've never read something like this before. It's written in an auto-biographical style as in he speaks about what his editor will say in certain areas and teaches you a new word he learned in the writing process. The cool part is, it doesn't take you out of the story.

As we are in Ern's head the entire time, a few chapters will be bunched together in a group entitled MY WIFE or MY BROTHER. You are aware you're going to find out who this certain person has killed, either past or present. Even at the beginning of the book, he tells you every page number there is a murder. You better believe I was flipping back and forth to check. Everything was not as it seemed even though he technically did not lie. It was ambitious. It was executed flawlessly.

Be prepared to give this novel your full attention as you start it. It took me longer to read to appreciate the intricacies. It's not a knock on the book. Just set that expectation so A. you don't miss anything and B. you don't find it cumbersome. 

Nothing in this book is supernatural or convenient. This story is just plain smart and I 100% recommend this.

Ended 2022 with a four star 😍

The Siren
By Katherine St. John
TW: yes, DM me

Read if you like…
-following tabloids
-reading about the rich and famous
-movie sets
-learning about hurricanes and storms
-watching tell-alls 

This story had a ton of moving parts. That alone explains the necessity for the higher page count. Within this novel contains a mystery, a few different romances (all of which I rooted for), an overall contemporary feel, and a revenge story. How the heck Katherine pulled it all off, I’ll never know. 

I thoroughly enjoyed this story. I would recommend reading it with your eyes as listening to it can be a tad bit confusing. The plot twists didn’t surprise me, but I’m not sure that was the intent of them. What was cool was actually having a mystery aspect to it. I went in blind so I wasn’t expecting it. It was fun. 

Toward the end, a hurricane hits the island they’re filming on (not a spoiler) and I almost felt as if that part could’ve been left off. To me, the story would not have lost anything if the hurricane didn’t exist. 

Not a jab at the book, just a personal opinion there and the reason for a star missing!

Overall, I recommend this! There are quite a few trigger warnings so if those bother you, be sure to do your due diligence in looking those up or just DM me. 

So excited to read more of her work!

I can't put into words the absolute chokehold this author duo has on me. I'm a hoe for Greer and Sarah and I will not apologize for such.

THE GOLDEN COUPLE
By: Greer Hendricks and Sarah Pekkanen
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Read this if you..
-love dual POV
-enjoy secrets that are revealed throughout a story
-go to therapy
-want to own your own boutique
-know a person that gives you the heebie jeebies

Synopsis:
Wealthy Washington suburbanites Marissa and Matthew Bishop seem to have it all—until Marissa is unfaithful. Beneath their veneer of perfection is a relationship riven by work and a lack of intimacy. She wants to repair things for the sake of their eight-year-old son and because she loves her husband. Enter Avery Chambers.

Avery is a therapist who lost her professional license. Still, it doesn’t stop her from counseling those in crisis, though they have to adhere to her unorthodox methods. And the Bishops are desperate

Thoughts:
My favorite part about this story was learning about the unorthodox way Avery chose to run her therapy sessions, inside and outside of the room. Marissa was the suburban wife who had an affair on her seemingly perfect husband. While exploring that dynamic and watching Marissa become more confident was interesting, my excitement brewed every other chapter when I was able to read about Avery. 

Avery is smart. She is detail-oriented. She catches on to things. Her mind is sharp and she isn't afraid to get into the weeds. Avery is scared of one thing though, and while it would be a spoiler to give that away, I would be spooked too. The best part about Avery is she isn't the dumb female MC. The intricacies of her life and her sleuthing had me excited to read her chapters.

It's hard to compare Avery and Marissa's chapters as they were different characters. One is dealing with her own infidelities, her feelings toward that, wondering who she can trust and learning to take control of her own life. While the other is dealing with protecting herself, learning to soften some edges, figuring out secrets in unorthodox ways, and her own personal battles.

I would definitely recommend this to someone who doesn't like open ended stories.

THIS PLOT TWIST THO

MAGPIE 
By: Elizabeth Day
⭐️⭐️⭐️✨ (3.5)
TW: yes, DM me

Read this if you..
-have had weird roommates
-have a MIL who is less than ideal
-sometimes just need a stiff drink
-enjoyed the show YOU

Synopsis:
Marisa and Jake are a perfect couple, and Kate, their new lodger, is the perfect roommate--and not just because her rent payments will give them the income they need to start trying for a baby. Except no one is perfect. Sure, Kate doesn’t seem to care much about personal boundaries and can occasionally seem overly familiar with Jake, but Marisa doesn’t let it concern her. Kate will soon be gone, and it will just be her, Jake, and their future baby. Right?

Thoughts:
The twist was great, the ending was too convenient for my liking. Add those together and you get the solid 3.5 stars. 

This was a harder read. I really enjoyed it, but I am not a sensitive reader. It evoked emotions of anger, frustration, and made me question my own thought process a few times. Bravo to Day for being able to make the reader feel and think differently while reading!

Jake and Marissa have a really great life but need to let Kate move in to help with rent as they prepare to be new parents. But Kate doesn't seem to have boundaries which is really freaking Marissa out. Marissa resorts to some... unique tactics.

While the story of following this couple and the lodger was fun, the ending followed one of my personal least favorite tropes. I was ready and wanted it to get super dark. I was prepared for it. It lead up to it. And it didn’t hit it. I was a little disappointed in that. 

Overall, I liked this book! I can't wait to hear your thoughts as well!

Mini reviews on two genres you don’t ever (and probably shouldn’t) come to me for but…

THE TOBACCO WIVES by Adele Myers (historical fiction) ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

THE REUNION by Kayla Olson (romance) ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

I know right? Kait giving romance and HF 4 and 5 stars? We don’t know who she is either

The Tobacco Wives was a pleasant read about the days before America knew the dangers of tobacco. We follow a young dressmaker who is tasked with making the dresses of the wealthy tobacco tycoon’s wives. I love a story about the rich and famous which is why I gravitated to this. 

There’s love, ethical dilemmas, and the insight of how tobacco destroyed lives and homes. 

It was a great reprieve from the macabre I read. 

The Reunion was a low stakes romance following tv stars who are doing a television reunion 14 years after the original wrapped. Liv and Ransom were on-screen lovers and off-screen bffs. But of course there are actual feelings off screen. 

I am learning I love a low-stress romance conflict. This gave me the pining I so desperately wanted and the ending I desperately needed. 

Now back to the creepy and twisty books🤍

If you’re brand new to thrillers and are a little intimidated, this list is for you. Here are my OG thrillers that helped me jump into the genre. When I look at these books, I actually smile? Idk it’s like looking at the beginning of something. The nostalgia. 

Verity by Colleen Hoover: first time I read romance within a thriller that I didn’t hate

Dark Matter by Blake Crouch: the science fiction in here is explained thoroughly and added such an incredible element. My first look into science fiction within thrillers

The Lying Game by Ruth Ware: the third thriller I ever read. I was SHOCKED at the twist 

Gone Girl by Gillian Flynn: the real OG. Nothing can ever top the feeling of reading this one for the first time 

The One by John Marrs: the first time I was exposed to so many POVs (and it’s just a great book)

Before I Go To Sleep by S. J. Watson: the second thriller I ever read. I remember sneaking it in my college classes

Final Girls by Riley Sager: one of my favorite backlist Sager books. This was my first one of his

Thriller lovers: do you agree? Should I have added any others? 
Those getting into the genre: have you read these yet? I want to hear your thoughts! 

I want to see your nostalgia posts!

I asked for horror and this book DELIVERED.

EPISODE THIRTEEN 
By: Craig DiLouie
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Read this if you..
-watch Ghost Hunters
-care about science
-want to know the ins and outs of how a show is made
-enjoyed how Illuminae was written (multimedia format)

Synopsis: Fade to Black is the newest hit ghost hunting reality TV show. It’s led by husband and wife team Matt and Claire Kirklin and features a dedicated crew of ghost-hunting experts.
 
Episode Thirteen takes them to Matt's holy grail: the Paranormal Research Foundation. This crumbling, derelict mansion holds secrets and clues about the bizarre experiments that took place there in the 1970s. It's also, undoubtedly, haunted, and Matt hopes to use their scientific techniques and high tech gear to prove it. 

But, as the house begins to slowly reveal itself to them, proof of an afterlife might not be everything Matt dreamed of. 
 
A story told in broken pieces, in tapes, journals, correspondence, and research files, this is the story of Episode Thirteen — and how everything went horribly wrong.

Thoughts:
I had no idea this would be told in journal entries, emails, manuscripts, and actual photos. That made this 400 page horror novel not as daunting. 

I enjoyed being able to get to know each character throughout their time on the show and slow descents into madness. There were a few slow moments for me but the hauntings and absolutely creepy-ness of the house and what they experienced made it all worth it. It was a quick read due to the style of writing, too.

I thoroughly enjoyed the science behind ghosts and watching someone try to debunk what was going on. As a skeptic myself, that was so fun and interesting. 

The hauntings weren't even the scariest part. Seeing how each person was affected AFTER/DURING the hauntings scared me the most. I loved diving into how each person handled fear differently. 

I would def recommend this! Just maybe not to my easily spooked friends 😉

Thank you Redhook and Craig for the gifted final copy! This is available now!

Baking shows and murders? Bro ok

THE GOLDEN SPOON
By: Jess’s Maxwell
⭐️⭐️⭐️

Synopsis:
A killer is loose on the set of a famous baking competition show. At first it’s sabotage. Dishes are messed up, ingredients switched around. But then someone dies. And it can only be one of the people in the manor in which the show is filmed. 

Read if you…
-liked locked room thrillers
-watch baking/cooking shows
-are interested in behind the scenes
-would die to meet your idol

My thoughts:
I didn’t love it I didn’t hate it. I think it’s a great premise but the stakes weren’t high enough. What I did love were the vastly different characters. Those were fun to read about. 

But man, the stakes just weren’t high enough until all of the sudden they were? We went from a sugar mishap to murder? It was quite a jump there. 

Also, if I were running a baking competition and realized that every time the cameras were rolling that someone’s dish didn’t turn out well and they explained that things were switched around, idk I’d take that more seriously? There were some choices made (or not made) by the staff that were odd. 

At the end of the day, I’d still recommend this! The story and premise were fun even if the execution bothered me a little. 

Thank you @atriabooks for this gifted copy! This is out in April!

Just The Nicest Couple - book review 
By Mary Kubica
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Read this if you…
-have an ailing or sick family member that requires extra assistance from the family
-trust your spouse over anything
-are a school teacher

Synopsis: Jake Hayes is missing. At first, his wife, Nina, thinks he is blowing off steam at a friend’s house after their heated fight the night before. But then a day goes by. Two days. Five. And Jake is still nowhere to be found.

Lily Scott, Nina’s friend and coworker, thinks she may have been the last to see Jake before he went missing. After Lily confesses everything to her husband, Christian, the two decide that nobody can find out what happened leading up to Jake’s disappearance, especially not Nina. But Nina is out there looking for her husband, and she won’t stop until the truth is discovered.

My thoughts: ok. I read this in two plane rides. My husband asked me to watch a show and I was disappointed to put this book down (but the show was good so it made up for it.)

Is this predictable? Ehhh.. some could say that you could possibly think of the conclusion if you tried. However, I’m every thriller author’s target audience: I don’t try to figure it out along the way. I am along for the ride. And boy was this a ride. 

It was fun because you have Lily and Christian over here trying to ensure Lily is covered. Then you have Nina over there trying to figure out what happened to her husband. The fun parts were 1. We didn’t really know what happened to Christian even though Lily is confessing things and 2. Things are happening to Nina and she’s finding out things that are clearly nothing related to Lily and Christian. It was a race but they weren’t always racing against each other. I loved that!

The twist did get me. I genuinely wasn’t expecting it. Looking back, I could’ve if I tried, but I didn’t see it coming. 

The ending does tie up in a bow if that’s your favorite kind of thriller ending! 

I loved this so much.

I don't wanna talk about this one. Ok here we go.

The Island
By Adian McKinty
⭐️⭐️✨ (2.5 stars)

Read this if you...
-need a survival thriller in your life
-want to read a Karin Slaughter but need it subdued a little
-want to read about twisted, Australian hillbillies with a barbaric side? idk

Synopsis:
Heather Baxter marries Tom, a widowed doctor with a young son and teenage daughter. A working vacation overseas seems like the perfect way to bring the new family together, but once they’re deep in the Australian outback, the jet-lagged and exhausted kids are over it.

When they discover remote Dutch Island, off-limits to outside visitors, the family talks their way onto the ferry, taking a chance on an adventure far from the reach of phone service. 

But as soon as they set foot on the island, which is run by a tightly knit clan of locals, everything feels wrong. Then a shocking accident propels the Baxters into an absolute nightmare.

My thoughts:
Sigh
I really enjoyed the first like 1/3 of this. I enjoyed the buildup. I didn't like any of the characters much, but I'm not one that has to like a character to like the book. 

But then the buildup fizzled and it just plateaued? I know there was supposed to be tension, but I never felt it. It was like "omg there are sharks in here" but you just always knew they were going to make it past the sharks. (not a spoiler) (you can really tell) 

Maybe I have high expectations from watching these shows growing up or reading survival thrillers as a teenager but I was bored and the ending did nothing for me. I'm sad.

Let me know if you agree or disagree! I know this is a polarizing book you either love or hate and I'm excited to hear your thoughts.

I get why you either love or hate this one

Insomnia
By Sarah Pinborough
3.5 stars

Read this if you...
-need a genuine psychological thriller
-repetition without remembering freaks you out
-want something a little speculative??
-pop that melatonin to go to sleep every night (where my ppl at)

Synopsis:
Emma Averell worries that her crippling insomnia is a sign that she’s slowly going insane—like the mother she’s worked so hard to leave in her past.

Literally this is all you need to know.

My thoughts:
I've had this book on my shelf as a highly anticipated read for a while. I actually really enjoyed most of it.

Anything with repetition where the person doesn't remember doing it freaks me out. Think "All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy" from The Shining movie. There are a few scenes in here where she sees she's done something but genuinely can't remember doing it. Loved those.

As it gets to the end and her madness and insomnia continues, I could tell the author was really struggling with making this book last 300 pages. The "craziness" and verbal accusations of "you're making me do this" or "You set this up!" lasted well beyond it's welcome. That's the repetition I didn't need here. 

As it counts down to her birthday (which is the same birthday her mother also went clinically insane) she becomes more and more unhinged. She can't sleep. She's up at night with sheer paranoia. Her kids are scared of her now. Her husband is put out by her. 

The ending is a little out there. It’s different. It’s a little odd. And I really liked it. That’s all I can really say about it!

Here are the things that made this not a five star for me: 
-all of this happened in just like 7 days. I wish this were over a span of a month or two. I think a slower burn would've made this better for me.
-IF SHE WOULD HAVE JUST TALKED ABOUT IT, HER FAMILY WOULDN'T HAVE REACTED IN SUCH A WAY
-girl, I get you're all tired and close to going insane from no sleep, but if you don't stop blaming everyone around you to every person who talks to you, imma slap you

Overall, I did enjoy it! Just not as much as I was hoping. 

What did you think about it? Have you read this yet?

I have officially rated every Greer and Sarah book 4 or 5 stars. 

The Wife Between Us
By Greer Hendricks and Sarah Pekkanen
4 stars

Read this if you...
-like a stalker story
-need that good plot twist
-need another good plot twist
-hate men

Synopsis:
When you read this book, you will make many assumptions.
You will assume you are reading about a jealous ex-wife.
You will assume she is obsessed with her replacement – a beautiful, younger woman who is about to marry the man they both love.
You will assume you know the anatomy of this tangled love triangle.
Assume nothing.

My thoughts:
I believe this twist has been done a few times since the dynamic duo wrote this book in 2018. But, I believe they were one of the first to do this twist. Keep that in mind when you read this.

I love the fact this book was written many years ago and it's still holding up to thrillers today. This goes to show how incredible this premise is, and how amazing of a writing pair we get to read from. 

I really do love watching the rise and fall of the main character as she makes her way through jealousy, obsession, and lowkey rage sometimes. Then as each twist comes to light, it genuinely makes you wonder if everything you know is true or not. It was perfect.

I do recommend reading this with your eyes. I listened via audio and at times I found myself wishing I could re-read a few paragraphs to really grasp how things change. Physical format is best for this book.

Greer and Sarah are pioneers and I will forever read what they write.

Ghost Eaters
By Clay McLeod Chapman
4 stars

This isn’t for the weak stomached. Going into this, I was expecting something a little more thriller (even though the cover is terrifying) and lemme tell ya, I was wrong

Read this if you…
-like a little gore
-enjoy reading about grief
-are intrigued about being haunted

Synopsis:
Erin hasn’t been able to set boundaries with her ex boyfriend. When he calls and asks her to bail him out of rehab, she knows she needs to cut him off. But after he gets out, he’s found dead of an overdose. Then a friend tells her about Ghost, a new drug that allows users to see the dead. But the side effects are unfathomable. “Want to get haunted?” 

Thoughts: 
This was so unique. Instead of buildings being haunted, the people were. As we follow Erin down a path of grief and addiction (TW), we read some truly uncomfortable yet important scenes that genuinely has stuck with me. Although one particular scene is still in my head and it was disturbing and I low key wish it would leave (iykyk)

This story invokes many different emotions. I felt disgusted, sad, stressed, and a little reprieve here and there. This story was fun and deep. I thoroughly enjoyed being able to actually feel her fear and her longing for Silas. Chapman did a wonderful job showing a mental decline. 

I’d recommend this to fellow horror lovers!

I asked for horror and I got it. Let’s go

HOW TO SELL A HAUNTED HOUSE
By Grady Hendrix
4 stars

Read this if you…
-like to be freaked out but want more depth
-enjoy reading through the grief process
-freaking hate puppets
-have family drama

What I liked:
This was genuinely creepy. Kinda gory. I don’t necessarily enjoy gory but there was the right amount that grossed you out but didn’t make you out the book down. This handled grief INCREDIBLY well. In fact, one could argue this was a book about grief with some horror mixed in. Grief is hard. It’s long. It doesn’t look the same to everyone and Hendrix did a fantastic job displaying that. 

This also made me want to put away every doll and stuffed animal I own and/or have ever owned. Seriously. 

What wasn’t my favorite:
It was a tad long for me and I lost interest a little during Mark’s (little brother) story. I felt as if it went on a little long and found myself skimming a little. 

That’s literally the only thing I didn’t like. 

Bravo, Hendrix.

What are your thoughts on this one?

You want a fun, fast paced story? Try epistolary writing! Basically, the story is written in forms of letters, interviews, text messages, podcast format, etc. 

This is a really fun way to read a story - especially a thriller! Plus it seems like it’s faster to get through, making them great weekend reads!

Some of my favorites include:
Sadie by Courtney Summers
The Appeal by Janice Hallett
The Twyford Coe by Janice Hallett
Cover Story by Susan Regetti
Episode Thirteen by Craig DiLouie

I would’ve loved this if this were the first thriller I’d ever read

No seriously, if I wasn’t a thriller veteran and I read this early on, I’d be able to contribute my love of thrillers to this book. 

THINGS WE DO IN THE DARK
By Jennifer Hillier
3.5 stars

I hate giving it 3.5 because it would’ve been a 5 star years ago 

Read this if you…
-like in depth dual timelines
-are intrigued by the rich
-wish you had an inheritance

What I liked:
I actually really loved the characters in this story. There are some trigger warnings (DM me if needed) and this is somewhat hard to get through at times. I really loved the twist. I saw it from a mile away which was disappointing to me, but it was still executed flawlessly. The family and friend dynamic is spelled out well and there was no miscommunication or convenience tropes which I appreciated. 

Seriously a great thriller for those getting into the genre!

What wasn’t my favorite:
Ugh I saw the twist from a mile away. I’m never one to guess the twist early on but had no choice. It just stared at me. I tried to ignore it but I couldn’t. I hate that so much because the twist really is great. 

I also didn’t like how the MC and her friend’s relationship felt rushed. I’d love a few more pages of dialogue and exposition with them as it felt…. Unfinished? 

All in all, great first-ish thriller to get into the genre. And I did enjoy it!

We’ve been reading over here! Here are three recent books I’ve read and how I’ve rated them

Spare by Prince Harry - NR: I’m not rating this one but I loved it. I appreciate any kind of memoir as I know it can’t be easy to divulge secrets and put life down on paper like that. I’ve read other reviews, I see others hate it, I don’t care. I did get a little bored in the middle when only talking about the war, but in the grand scheme it was needed to further paint the picture of who he is as a whole. Well done. 

Twyford Code by Janice Hallett - 2 stars: I read this with my book club and I’m so upset I didn’t love this like I loved her first one. This book markets itself as epistolary but is mainly just audio files. I felt as if I was reading a straight novel because the format never changed. While the ending was super cool, it just didn’t save it for me. 

A House with Good Bones by T. Kingfisher - 4 stars: this was spooky! But not in the only-read-during-the-day kind of spooky. Just the right amount. I thoroughly enjoyed this story, I loved the ominous sections, I loved it was less than 300 pages. I didn’t love the copious amounts of parenthesis in the text as if she were talking to the reader in a comment. But that’s just me being picky as it didn’t take away from the story!

This was a horror novel with a mystery embedded and I’m HERE for it

The Spite House
By Johnny Compton
4 stars

Read if you…
- enjoyed watching Get Out
- need a little more story with your horror
- are claustrophobic 
- okay maybe if you’re NOT claustrophobic…
- actually want to be freaked out

What I liked:
This had sustenance. I’m beginning to realize I am not a fan of straight paranormal horror. It’s predictable and somewhat boring to me. This had a deeper layer where even though I was getting scared by creepy hallways, I was still learning about the characters and finding myself rooting for some and hating others - which was the point. 

There is a mystery throughout this regarding WHY this dad and two daughter trio were running and would even be willing to take this job looking after a self-reported haunted house. Each family member has their secret they believe keeps the family safe. We get POVs from each character mentioned throughout the novel which is interesting to me as well. 

Whether or not a book is “scary” is way subjective, but this hit the mark for me. I found myself not particularly wanting to read this at night and the hallway scenes ✨did✨ it for me. Some of you might not think this was all that scary, to which I say you’re braver than me and I will pick you for a haunted house stay anytime. 

I thoroughly enjoyed the deeper dive into family dynamics, odd intentions from housekeepers, and unraveling the mystery behind the family as well as the woman who owns the house alongside the horror. They balanced nicely. 

What wasn’t my favorite:
The youngest daughter is 7 and her POV was written more like a baby adult and not a 7 year old. I get it, she’s been through a lot and has probably grown up more than I had to at 7, but I think a little childlike essence would’ve been a fun touch to this - especially as a haunted house book. 

Thank you to @tornightfire @comptonwrites for this advanced release of this novel and thank you to @atlascoffeeclub for sponsoring my caffeine addiction!

Another “if you’ve read this popular book (survive the night by Riley Sager) then you might like this more unpopular book” (five total strangers by Natalie D. Richards)

While Survive the Night is more adult with just a driver and passenger and Five Total Strangers veers YA with five passengers in a car, I think they give off the same vibe. 

Here’s why:
-both MCs want to escape the car eventually in the story
-both evoke the sense of dread
-both make decisions that confuse the reader but make sense in the end
-both make you hate men

While the endings are completely different, these comparable titles both make you feel the same things throughout the story.

If this is realistic, I’m never flying again 🥲

Falling by T. J. Newman (not to be confused with Drowning by T. J. Newman that comes out later this month) was a 4 star for me!

I really liked how each character had their moment to step up to the plate and have their moment. This was a true suspense thriller with a few twists along the way to keep you entertained. 

I’d read this if you enjoyed Hostage by Clare Mackintosh! They both had that impending doom vibe. 

We follow a pilot who realizes his plane has been hijacked by a FaceTime call. This FaceTime call shows his family kidnapped with a message to redirect the plane, or his family will die. Ok😅

Throughout the story, we don’t know who is in on it on the flight, we just know someone isn’t telling the truth. 

One thing that wasn’t my favorite was the POV from the detective. While it didn’t come in as often as the pilot’s side of things, I think it would’ve been more intense if we KNEW that detective stuff was going on, but we didn’t see it play out side by side. 

Like I said, true suspense thriller. Great on audio! Easy weekend read. Plus good time to read it before Drowning hits bookstores!

According to goodreads, I have a very unpopular opinion….

I didn’t like it. This wasn’t a book for me. 

Now here are some things I did enjoy:

-the few final twists
-the representation
-honestly want to be the grandmother when I grow up

-the women all sounded the same. Thank you @cozypagesss for sending an outline of who is who in our buddy read chat otherwise I would’ve been lost
-I feel this book would’ve been better with about 70 pages cut off. It was extremely verbose and description heavy. Others really love that type of writing but it’s never been my style

Ready for another “if you love this popular book, you should read this not-as-popular book (or vice versa)?”

If you read and enjoyed The Silent Patient by Alex Michaelides, you should read The Black Painting by Neil Olson. 

Here’s why:
Both stories revolve around a painting. I’m The Silent Patient, we have Alicia’s self-portrait to help with the story as she hasn’t spoken a word since the “incident.” In The Blank Painting, the story revolves around a self-portrait and the secrets it holds. When four cousins are summoned to their grandfather’s mansion, they’re shocked to find the old man’s corpse staring in terror at the very spot where the painting once was. 

Both are super mysterious, both border creepy, both revolve around a painting, both have main characters that can’t and won’t tell their own story. 

Have you read either of these?! I need to hear your thoughts!

Just recently read these three thrillers and I must say, they were so fun! Here are some mini reviews/thoughts about these popular thrillers. 

Reckless Girls by Rachel Hawkins - 4 stars
This locked room/island mystery was so much fun. This vacation turned nightmare story revolves around the destruction of relationships and secrets revealed while trapped on an island longer than anticipated. Would recommend if you liked One by One by Ruth Ware!

Stay Awake by Megan Goldin - 5 stars
Before I Go To Sleep meets Momento and I ATE THIS UP. Stories like these have a tendency to repeat itself to hit a page count - this one didn’t whatsoever. Two different POVs and multiple timelines to follow. This revolves around Liv Reese who forgets everything from the past two years every single time she wakes up. Like imagine getting on a plane that day for a spontaneous vacation, taking a nap on the plane, waking up, and not even remembering where you’re going or why you’re on a plane. Insanity. 

Daisy Darker by Alice Feeney - 4 stars
Idk what goodreads says, this is a banger. And Then There Were None with a twist at the end? Yes absolutely. We are following the Darker family on a remote island to celebrate the matriarch’s birthday. And just like you might think, one by one they start showing up dead. I loved the story, I loved the twist, I had fun. 

Out of these three, which one is your favorite?? Do you disagree with me at all?

-can’t live without your coffee

What I loved:
Okay this gripped me. This book is unique where the story kind of switches in the middle, but you don’t catch on until the end. It’s seamless. And then it all comes together. 

Alix Summers, a popular podcaster, and a seemingly nobody, Josie Fair, are celebrating their 45th birthdays separately at the same pub. They’re birthday twins. Alix and Josie run into each other again and Josie convinces Alix to do a podcast about Josie. You see, Josie is about to change her life and thinks it would be cool to document it as it happens. Alix being bored with her content agrees and the interviews again. 

Then we realize Josie is weird af but Alix is so invested, she can’t stop interviewing her. (You’ll see why, I don’t think I’d be able to stop either) But then Josie ends up conning her way into Alix’s life and home?? And now Josie has disappeared?? And Alix is now entangled in her own podcast?! *screams internally*

Amazing. Entertaining. Fast-paced. I was never confused whose pov I was reading from. Perfect number of characters. The queen has done it again. 

Lisa, I bow down. 

(Thank you to @lisajewelluk and @atriabooks for this advanced copy!)

This might be my favorite edition of “if you’ve read this one, you’ll love this one” 

If you’ve read No Exit by Taylor Adams, you’ll love The Overnight Guest by Heather Gudenkauf (or vice versa)

Both stories contain…
-winter isolation
-survival instincts 
-a child to save 
-someone else who doesn’t want the child to be found

These are such different stories that if you read one right after the other, you wouldn’t feel as if you were reading the same thing over again. But they have the same vibe, the same ambiance, evoke the same panic feeling. They fall into the same group without being the same story. 

No Exit involves more characters and a kidnapped child. The Overnight Guest involves one main character, another, and a child she found outside in the winter storm. Both include the need for smart decisions to be made, a sense of doom, and a deep desire for it to be the morning time. 

Thoroughly loved both of these!!

What do you think? Know if any others that can fit into this book group? Have you read these?

Perfect pool-with-a-view book? Absolutely. 

We follow two bffs who con men. (Iconic) 
They’ll do anything for each other. But then one goes missing… and her bff thinks she’s on an island with a man… 

I love my bff but this relationship puts mine to SHAME. I’m talking Summer does some incredible antics to get Leo back. Does she even come back? WHERE IS SHE AND WHY CANT SUMMER GET OFF THIS ISLAND. 

I read this while in a pretty spot (obvi look at the pic) and kept looking at my husband like “are you going to kidnap me” because the atmosphere was so great. 

Go into this one with a little less thriller expectation and I think you’ll enjoy it more. 

YOU CAN TRUST ME
By Wendy Heard

If you’ve seen my stories lately, you’ve seen this book. I’ve raved, I can’t stop thinking about it. 

THE LAST ONE by Will Dean is about a woman who goes on a lovely cruise with her boyfriend. They dine and laugh and have the best first day. She goes to sleep next to him and wakes up alone. She’s now the only one on the ship. 

Here’s the fun thing: this all happens within the first few pages. It’s also the only thing the synopsis tells you. Meaning the other 390 pages are a complete surprise. And let me tell you, this was a RIDE. 

I can literally not tell you anything else without respecting the synopsis and spoiling it so let me tell you how I felt while reading this:
I couldn’t stop. I devoured this 400 page book in 24 hours. My husband kept saying “wow you haven’t been this invested in a book in a while” and for good reason. Each twist came at me so quickly that I believe audible gasps escaped my mouth. 

I vote more books leave out more of the plot in the synopsis just for this experience alone. 

This book went in ways I didn’t expect AT ALL and I loved it. 

Bravo, @willrdean 
5 stars

To everyone and their mother who told me to read this for YEARS, I am so sorry and I owe you my life because this was a RIDE lemme tell ya. 

I’m giving this 4 stars. I can’t give it 5 for very personal opinions and nothing to do with the writing or story itself. There were just a few choices that didn’t sit well with me and that’s ok! Because listen, this is a good book. 

There are trigger warnings so pls be aware and do your research 

Personally I loved the psychology behind the story. How something from your brain development years can really impact you as an adult. Reading this as an adult can make you think “why in the WORLD did you think or do that” but realizing teenage brain can impact adult brain so much was written well here

Different timelines that merge together in the end. Character arcs that kind of made me root for the villain (am I ok?). A very sudden abrupt end that actually made my mouth open in surprise. 

It’s a simple story really. A girl and her boyfriend killed the girl’s best friend when they were teenagers. They’re convicted of the crime many years later after they both kept the secret. We then follow her in jail and when she’s released, it seems like it’s happening again even though she claims she’s not the culprit. But where’s the boyfriend? Bc he escaped prison a long time ago and he miiiiight be coming for her idk 

The twist was twisty and it was a quick read. Didn’t see it coming. 

Freaking love a 4 star backlist! 

Jar of Hearts by Jennifer Hillier

Staying on brand with my reel today, I give you even more amazing books with an unreliable narrator! The story in and of itself is twisty. THEN you add on maybe not trusting the one telling you the story?? Love that SO much. Save this for when you need that extra layer of twist in your book

The Woman in Cabin 10 by Ruth Ware
The Silent Patient by Alex Michaelides
All the Dangerous Things by Stacy Willingham
Stay Awake by Megan Goldin
The Wife Between Us by Greer Hendricks and Sarah Pekkanen
Wrong Place Wrong Time by Gillian McAllister

What are some others out there?!

Finally a survival story without the gore!!!!

I’ve always loved the idea of a wilderness survival story but gore isn’t something I can read particularly well. I wanted to give this one a try because I like Lucy Clarke’s writing and I’m happy I did. 

We follow four adult best girl friends who take yearly trips together. They all have their own lives but make time to spend a week or two together every year. Normally they beach it but this year, she wanted something different. She wanted to hike a mountain. Literally no one wants to go but it’s her year to choose so they buy backpacks and tents and go. Did she mention they’ll be sleeping in sleeping bags for 3 days? 

I really loved the dynamic of the four women. It’s hard having a group of four sometimes. Two are always closer than others or there’s always some beef between those two over there. The girl drama and cat fights were intense but short lived as they trek throughout the elements. 

We learn each woman’s life and personal woes as the weather gets worse and more dangerous. Didn’t that woman say to not go because of a storm coming? Oh yeah…

The elements won over and over again as they realize just how ill prepared they were. And did we mention there’s a KILLER out there?! Yeah that too…

I gave this 4 stars!
The Hike by Lucy Clarke
Out august 29!

Allow me to introduce you to your newest fave cult-ish thriller: LAY YOUR BODY DOWN

This new release handles religious trauma and extremism with the upmost respect and delicacy. 

We are following Del in the present time as she has already left her church, The Messiah. Her ex boyfriend has passed away (sketchy?) and she finds herself walking back into The Mess for the funeral. She sees his wife (her ex best friend ooh drama) and her parents (they haven’t spoken in 6 years) plus the current pastor who made her life a living hell (pun intended).

Her ex bestie, Eve, is 100000% drinking The Messiah’s and Pastor Rick’s kool aid. She even has a viral blog called The Noble Wife where she teaches the masses what the pastor has taught her: how to be the best Proverbs 31 wife. (I too strive to be the Proverbs 31 wife but this blog.. oof)

Remember the “sketchy” comment? Yeah that’s why Del just can’t leave this place that gives her so much anxiety. It IS sketchy and she can’t get past it. 

Throughout the story we meet some pretty important characters and learn just how Pastor Rick’s charisma keeps everyone in line. 

This cult-like thriller has a few plot twists and kept me engaged as I just got angry at men. 

Pick this up! What other cult like books do you like? Are you going to read this? 

LAY YOUR BODY DOWN
By: Amy Suiter Clarke

They always say money can’t buy you happiness… but I promise if I had the money for all of these books, I’d be wayyyyy happier….. 

Shoutout to my Instagram husband for this one

THIS WAS SO FUN. 

I feel like I just read a fictional Real Housewives summer vacation and when I tell you I ate this up…

You have drama. You gave catty women. You have infidelity. You have women caring about something WAY too much (in this book it’s tennis. They are like way obsessed with tennis) and then there’s a dead body found?! Bro. 

What I liked was this book isn’t a book about murder and the characters are just rich, snobby people. It’s a book about rich, snobby people and there just happens to be a murder at the end (not a spoiler)

This was fun and a super quick read. It was like a tell-all, tabloid on steroids about fictional people. I loved and hated each character. 

Pick this 4.5 star read up and just have fun with it. The audio was great!

Bad Summer People 
By: Emma Rosenblum

I’m not normally a reader of your typical police procedural-esque books. But when I saw this was from a dual POV of a medical examiner, my first thought was “ooooh I bet that gets gruesome”

I wasn’t disappointed 

WHEN I’M DEAD does a phenomenal job at keeping you on your toes while introducing and handling emotions and pressures we feel as adults. Like managing your family and job at the same time and dealing with past traumas. 

I thought I had it. I really did. I thought I had the ending and I thought I knew who was behind *checks synopsis to make sure I’m not giving anything away* a murder and a missing girl. But I did NOT have it. I was actually pretty far off which made this even MORE fun to read. 

We read from multiple POVs which I personally love. Each perspective played their part immaculately and told their story without a page too many. 

Again, as someone who doesn’t normally gravitate toward procedural type stories, this book defies those stereotypes and is worth the read. 

Also I was low key scared to open this locket when I received it in the mail (again iykyk)

WHEN IM DEAD
By Hannah Morrissey

Me? Leaving a bookstore with romances?? And being halfway done with one already??? See that’s what happens when you walk into two bookstores with @lenareads__ 😂😂

Yesterday was magical. If it wasn’t for this community, my life would have a little less sparkle without Lena in it. 

She gave me her book in person and told me some incredible stories about her life. We realized we were ACTUALLY the same person and our husbands are eerily similar. We laughed a lot. And while we talked about books (look at her birthday haul!), we talked about life even more. It was the perfect day. 

Also can we talk about the romance book thing again??

I did a thing. And that thing was called “read a romance book”

I thought this was a cutie palate cleanser, but I’m ready for my macabre again. 

To sum up my thoughts because I’m not sure I know how to properly review a romance:
-I enjoyed it until the end, the end was too sped up for me and I can only suspend my disbelief so much
-Bree’s inner monologue reminded me of my 6 year old cousin on too much sugar
-Nathan was super sweet
-can we just have hard conversations pls it would speed things up
-their relationship was really cute

My goodreads review says just simply “bro” and I believe this sums this one up quite nicely

I was skeptical to pick this one up because of allll the hype it received. Lemme tell ya, it DESERVES all that hype. Plus some. 

The story was quick and fun but when you get to the end, you realize just how intricate it actually was. This book was smart. It got me. Multiple times. Then it got me again. I was bamboozled and I’m not mad about it. 

We’re following a seemingly perfect couple (Mr. And Mrs. Wright) as their marriage is all wrong (hahahaha I had to). They head on a little retreat to work on their marriage in a cute little cottage church thing she found. Of course it’s remote. Of course it’s creepy af when they get there. Of course it snows and they can’t leave. Why wouldn’t that happen?

Literally everything is going wrong. In the midst, we’re seeing letters she wrote him every anniversary that she’s never shared. They’re full of secrets and confessions. I was eating that part up. 

The TWIST 🤌🏼

Don’t mind my pumpkin pillow in the back as I read the best gothic thriller Christmas novella I’ve ever read

Y’all this was so fun! Less than 100 pages, you’ll easily blow through this in a single setting (which if you read the author’s note in the back, that’s exactly what Swanson desires to happen). 

We follow an American student named Ashley Smith who is studying abroad. It’s Christmas time and Ashley is about to spend the holidays alone until Emma Chapman invites her last minute to her estate called Cotswold Manor. Sure Emma’s parents are scary and Ashley’s room in the grand house is freezing but it’s just so cozy next to the fire and Ashley loves the idea of the holidays with a large family. (Plus the brother is cute ayyye)

The entirety of the book you’re figuring out if this is a grand romance or a gothic tale. Reading from journal entries the first half of the book and present day the second, Swanson does a great job with merging the two together and giving a good little twist in less than 100 pages!

5 stars!
THE CHRISTMAS GUEST
By Peter Swanson

I love this cover but the story was pretty average to me. I’m not someone who tries to figure out the ending before we get there, I love to just take the ride. However, I couldn’t help but call this one and was disappointed when I was correct. 

Read this if you 
-have a strained relationship with your sister
-absolutely adore your mom
-may be in love with your guy bff
-like a dual pov with one being in the past
-like reading a book in a book

We’re following a story of a MC who is struggling with the grief of her dead mother, a struggling relationship with her sister, and she’s head over heels in love with her childhood guy bff who’s married. Girl is just going through it. 

She has to return to her hometown for a high school friend’s vow renewal and she has to stay with her overbearing grandmother. But here’s the thing. Her mom’s death was ruled a suicide and she’s CONVINCED she was killed. So she’s using this time at home to truly figure out what happened to her mom. 

The second POV comes from her mom in the past. I loved that part! It was interesting to see her point of view throughout the story. 

I didn’t particularly enjoy the red herrings in this story. They were SO in your face that I could immediately tell they were false. I guess I just didn’t like how the story ended. It was rushed and improbable. 

This was my first May Cobb but it won’t be my last! I’m excited to give her others a chance. 

A Likeable Woman by May Cobb

Another popcorn thriller! Freida McFadden never disappoints on this fast-paced, get-through-them-quick reads. 

While reading this one, I wasn’t in awe of the story or the main protagonist, however I did enjoy the twist that came. I believe this book is best read with your eyes as opposed to an audiobook. 

Dawn, albeit a little strange, just wants to make office friends and doesn’t understand why she can’t relate to her office mates. This part really got to me as bullying or others being mean for someone being different is a personal trigger of mine. It did all come together in the end and I knew that McFadden would tie it up which is why I knew I could keep reading. 

Dawn has her precise schedule and she follows it to a T every single day. Then one day she just doesn’t show up to work. Her beautiful coworker, Natalie, goes by her house to check on her and finds a horrific crime scene. But now, somehow, Natalie is the number one suspect?

I enjoyed this one because of how fast paced it was, there were email threads that told another pov, and the end justifies the means. 

Like I said, quick popcorn thriller. Not her best but was entertaining!

The Coworker
By: Freida McFadden

This didn’t hit it for me and I’m SAD. While I found it just okay and mildly entertaining, it also took me DAYSSSS to read because I lost interest so many times throughout the story. 

I love Greek mythology as much as the next girl but this was heavily influenced by the history. The one thing that kept me intrigued more than most was the psychological aspects which are a normal theme in this author’s books. I love that about these stories. 

I found myself confused, bored, entertained then bored again, not connecting to any character while simultaneously intrigued by one in particular. Not that I liked being in his head, but I liked watching him from afar to see what he did. 

I found the story to be long winded. There were most definitely some thrilling aspects and scenes which had my pages flying, I just wanted that more than what I received. 

I would still recommend this to those who love Greek mythology, locked room thrillers, and enjoy reading what feels like a descent into madness.

I enjoyed this! While this wasn’t a horror like it might lead you to believe, it’s a thriller that had a bow-tied-up ending for those of you who don’t like open ended. 

The one aspect I feel is overdone nowadays is the woman who drinks too much but refuses to get help or believe it’s a problem so she becomes the unreliable narrator. It’s a bit overdone in my opinion and the trope can get a bit boring now. 

I did enjoy reading about the house’s past. We follow this wanna-be social media influencer who buys a fixer upper that just so happens to be the place a brutal murder happened. She wants to document the process on her blog and potentially get sponsorships. Whatever you gotta do to get that coin, sis

Of course there’s a weird history and past with old tenants and of course no one wants them there. 

While the story was nothing new, it was easily consumable and entertaining. A solid 1-2 day read and a great audio book. 

I’d recommend this to anyone wanting to dip their toes into a low key creepy book but doesn’t want to be too scared.

I finished this cutie of a romance while in the cutie of a city, La Spezia, Italy! 

I really loved Logan Arthur. I loved how unapologetically himself he was. I love how correct this book was about budget cuts and educational reformation. I loved how political this book was but was easily digestible. I loved watching Alexis become who she really is. 

This S L O W burn was just what I needed. I pined after this couple deeply and honestly appreciated the third act conflict represented here. Apparently I like fake dating romances? 

Winstead is a powerhouse of an author. With other romances I’ve read recently, just when you’re ready for them to get together, they get together. She makes you wait even longer. And I hated that and loved that so much. The payoff was worth it. She’s not afraid to push a boundary or two in her choices of timing and it works. 

Here we follow timid Alexis who is looking for a one night stand to get over her ex saying she was mousy in bed. She gathers the confidence and enters a swanky little bar. After being saved by Mr Logan Arthur, she realizes this is it. She’s about to have her ONS she’s never had before. Until the hotel bursts into flames and her ankle twists and now Logan is running away? Oof. 

They come into each other’s lives when she realizes he’s in the public eye and desperately needs her to pretend be his girlfriend. See, he’s got a bit of a playboy rep that really needs to die and a serious girlfriend would do that!

Alexis is a school librarian and cares deeply about her students’ access to books and art. With a mom in the public school system, this hit home. 

Romance and important topics were entertained expertly. 

The Boyfriend Candidate
By Ashley Winstead

Mini reviews for Mister Magic and The Senator’s Wife!

Mister Magic was my second read by Kiersten White. Her first wasn’t a success for me but her synopses still intrigue me. I know most people didn’t enjoy Mister Magic and I don’t know who I would recommend it to, but I actually liked it! 

It felt ominous, the story was compelling, and it was just really weird. The ending was even weirder. I genuinely understand why it has lower ratings but if you realize it’s a weird book with a weird ending, I think you’ll be able to accept it a little more. I’d almost compare this to a Sarah Gailey book. The tone was eerie but not scary and the story was original. 

I feel as if original plots get lower ratings because people haven’t read them before, therefore they’re uncomfortable or odd or not quite perfected. I thoroughly enjoy the creativity. They’re normally flawed because no one has been able to perfect it yet. This one gets a 3.5 star from me. 

The Senator’s Wife by Liv Constantine was almost a DNF for me, but more for personal triggers. Our main character has an autoimmune disease that is exploited and manipulated. I have an autoimmune disease. I can’t imagine someone switching out my insulin for something else so I get ill. That was hard for me to get through. 

I did it though and the payout was somewhat worth it. I did see one reveal from a mile away while the others were good surprises. 

If you’re into politics, the wealthy, exposing the dark natures of politicians, and calling out womanizers, this one might be for you. 

3 stars for me. 

I’d love to know your thoughts on these as well!

No but listen, I freaking loved this one. 

I really love books that do things out of the ordinary. Stories that take liberties, try new plot lines, do something odd. Nowadays, many stories follow the same formula and those that don’t? They deserve some extra love. Even if they’re weird. 

This love story to twilight, Bonnie and Clyde-like book deserves all the open minded-ness going in because it’s really good. It will make you think about relationships and decisions in ways you’ve never had to. 

Normally, the relationship is a no-brainer of what to root for. In this one? It’s slate gray and you get to decide. Neither decision is wrong. FREAKING LOVE THAT. 

We’re in a cult-like town following the pastor’s daughter. She is best friends with the town’s bad boy. She has an infatuation with twilight (same) and desires her non/existent love life to mirror Bella and Edward (same when I was 16)

People start dying and the town is blaming the demonic creature they’re all scared of. As more clues come to light, more people start to seem a little suspicious. 

If you’re looking for an ending with a pretty bow and the author tells you how to feel, this one isn’t for you. This ending is almost a “create your own adventure” type of story. 

I genuinely believe Ashley Winstead is an author ahead of her time. This genre-bending novel is perfect for someone in a reading slump who just doesn’t know what to read next. 

Midnight is the darkest hour
By: Ashley Winstead

Cate Quinn is an author who should be on your shelves immediately. 

I read her novel THE BLACK WIDOWS a few years ago on a whim and fell in love with Quinn’s writing style. She recently wrote THE CLINIC (coming out on January 23, 2024) and this is no exception. 

We are following Meg whose famous sister has died in a remote, luxury rehab clinic. Meg is seriously struggling with accepting the fact her sister is gone. When Meg, who has a few addictions herself but can stop any time she wants, checks herself into the same rehab facility, she’s determined to prove her sister was murdered. I mean, they haven’t talked in years but she just knows deep down. 

With a small, elite group also checked in who knew her sister, she has to fake her identity as she snoops around. But something seriously sinister is taking place around this clinic. Other people start to die. She can’t find out why her past nightmares are coming back to her, and now someone is trying to kill her? But there’s only like 6 people here! 

This was a truly fun read with an ending I PROMISE you don’t see coming. 

Such a good thriller and the perfect first 2024 read!!

A love letter to the authors here on Bookstagram:

You know, I had pretty selfish intentions when joining Bookstagram. My goal was to get bookmail. That was is. That was going to be how I knew I made it. 

I did it. I got the bookmail. I received the books from publishers and a following and a deeper knowledge of novels coming out soon. I’ve probably read them already. It was a point of pride. 

But you know what I’ve learned after 2.5 years on this platform? This isn’t about me whatsoever. This is my hobby. But I have the INCREDIBLE opportunity to showcase authors and their work. Authors who spend countless hours in front of a screen trying to create art. Authors who see a story in their mind and work tirelessly to write it in a way we see the same thing. Authors who try to shock us with twists and turns who probably feel a little burnt out at times. 

My favorite thing to do is spotlight an author or book that’s not the most popular. Of course I love reading and promoting the well-known authors and books, they’re well-known for a reason! But there are some authors out there that DESERVE that same recognition and just haven’t gotten it yet. 

When I get autographed books or a handwritten thank you card in the mail for simply taking a photo and putting it on my feed? When I’m able to have genuine conversations with an author in my DMs and get to know them as people? When I am able to help in giveaways? I’m humbled. 

So to all authors, thank you for your work. Thank you for putting your art into the world. Thank you for letting me read your books.

Willingham does this thing where her books get better each time she writes one, and this is no exception. 

writing thrillers this day in age can't be an easy thing to do. consumers have read just about every twist and authors are forced to write in a different way than before to capture readers' attention. honestly? what a stressful and hard thing to do.

she did it.

i love reading about toxic friendships, manipulation, and college settings. this had all three plus some. while there are some minor trigger warnings (feel free to DM me!) the story focused around the rise and fall of friendship and the inner workings of what caused the cracks. it was just a lot of fun.

if you are a fan of Ruth Ware's IT GIRL but felt it was a bit too long or focused too heavily on one POV, Willingham's book is for you. this story had multiple POVs but stayed mostly in the present, which is where the meat of the story was. 

you can tell she took her time with this one and enjoyed the story itself. it flowed well, it wasn't confusing, the twists were executed well.

5 stars from me and my favorite Willingham so far!

thank you @stacyvwillingham and @minotaur_books for the advanced copy of this book for an honest review in return. this book will be released in the wild on January 16, 2024!

Currently reading and really enjoying The Weekend Retreat by Tara Laskowski! 

I do this thing now where I read physical books at home and ensure I have it on my kindle so I can read my kindle everywhere else. Is it impractical? Yes. Do I care? Hahahahah no 

We have three couples all in the same family. As the siblings and their partners head to their estate and award winning winery for a birthday celebration, a storm (literally and figuratively) is brewing. Nowwww they’re stuck here with the rain and the hail and the no electricity thing. 

One sister is horrible and I love her. One brother is a sweetheart but kind of dumb. One seems to have it all together. I’m thoroughly enjoying the family dynamics and the author did a great job with the couple dynamics as well. You know how sometimes you don’t like your sister in law? (Not me I actually love mine) She did a phenomenal job describing those relationships. 

I’m about 80% in and we’re getting to the good stuff.

Mini reviews!

I’ve read these two books recently and wanted to share some thoughts. 

Drowning Woman by Robyn Harding: loved this. A great domestic thriller with some unexpected twists and turns and a REALLY unexpected ending. We follow a homeless woman who witnesses another woman drowning in the ocean. As she saves the drowning woman, secrets almost immediately start to come out. There’s some backstabbing, some betrayal, and some women showing how tough women can be. 

The Blackhouse by Carole Johnstone: I didn’t love this. I’m glad it’s marketed as a gothic thriller because it’s every sense of that phrase. I found this to be WAY too slow and quite frankly a little boring at times - which is so odd because this premise sounded amazing. You’d love this if you love a slow burn and some historical fiction. 

Have you read these? What are your thoughts?
